examples.en: The sales have gradually declined.
examples.ja: だんだん売り上げが落ちてきた。

examples.en: How's the DVD selling?
examples.ja: DVDの売り上げはどうですか？

examples.en: Sales have decreased rapidly because of that sexist advertisement.
examples.ja: あの性差別の広告のせいで、売り上げが激減した。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sell</kanji>ing that you've raised (上げ) is the <vocabulary>amount sold</vocabulary> or number of <vocabulary>sales</vocabulary>. Think of a graph going upward, where it's rising as you sell more things.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 売 is the one you learned with 売る. The reading for 上げ is the same as the reading for 上げる, a word you learned previously. If you know those two separate things, you should be able to combine them into one awesome vocab thing.

examples.en: Ramen is all sold out for today.
examples.ja: 今日のラーメンは全部売り切れです。

examples.en: The popular band's concert tickets were sold out in a minute from the release.
examples.ja: 人気のバンドのコンサートチケットは、発売から一分で売り切れてしまった。

examples.en: This book was sold out for a long time, but it finally came back in stock!
examples.ja: この本、ずっと売り切れだったんだけど、やっと再入荷したのよ！

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>sell</kanji>ing is <kanji>cut</kanji>, that means something is <vocabulary>sold out</vocabulary>. You'll see this word a lot in stores (or, hopefully you won't...) in Japan. Look out for it if you're able!
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: The seller was a man.
examples.ja: 売り手は男でした。

examples.en: The seller of the house was a famous idol singer.
examples.ja: 家の売り手は有名なアイドルでした。

examples.en: Isn't this transaction too advantageous for the seller?
examples.ja: この取引、売り手にとって有利すぎない？

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 手 can mean “doer”? Here, we have a <kanji>sell</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji>. Who might that be? It’s someone who does selling – a <vocabulary>seller</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>vendor</vocabulary>.

売り手 is usually used when talking about sellers versus buyers.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too! One hint that this is a kun'yomi reading word is the hiragana in the center. It's like two separate words combined together, and when a word is a single kanji / a single kanji with hiragana attached it is usually kun'yomi. This is like two of those, combined.

examples.en: The wedding party is tonight.
examples.ja: ウェディングパーティーは今夜です。

examples.en: I will go to the gym alone tonight.
examples.ja: 今夜は一人でジムに行きます。

examples.en: You may see Mercury in the west tonight.
examples.ja: 今夜は西の方に水星が見えるかもしれません。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>night</kanji> is the current night, aka <vocabulary>tonight</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi reading for 夜 yet, so here's a mnemonic:

<vocabulary>Tonight</vocabulary>, you're going to a <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や) baseball game. Not just any game, not just any night — the Yankees, tonight.

examples.en: I was volunteering in Tohoku.
examples.ja: 東北で、ボランティアをしていました。

examples.en: Tohoku beef is delicious.
examples.ja: 東北の牛肉はおいしいです。

examples.en: My grandmother is originally from Tohoku, so she understands the dialect.
examples.ja: 私のおばあちゃんは東北生まれなので方言が分かります。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>East</kanji> <kanji>North</kanji> area of Japan is called <vocabulary>Tohoku</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>Tohoku region</vocabulary>. It was the region hit by the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake. 

This can also mean <vocabulary>northeast region</vocabulary> when talking about China or Japan, but for other countries (and for the compass direction), we'd use 北東.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't seen the on'yomi reading for 北 (ほく) yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

In <vocabulary>Tohoku</vocabulary> there's a lot of <reading>hocu</reading>s (ほく) pocus going on. Basically, if you're in Japan's northeast, watch out… A lot of mountain hermits live up in those parts, practicing their weird hocus pocus. Don't let 'em getcha.

examples.en: I determined to propose on Mt. Fuji.
examples.ja: ふじ山の上でプロポーズすると決心した。

examples.en: My determination to "become a hero" is strong.
examples.ja: 私の「ヒーローになる」という決心は強いです。

examples.en: Have you found the resolve to study chemistry at university?
examples.ja: 大学で化学を学ぶ決心はつきましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>decide</kanji> with your <kanji>heart</kanji> you have true <vocabulary>determination</vocabulary>, unlike when you decide with your mind.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you take note of the shortened つ. So, けつ goes to けっ.

examples.en: My grandma joined the group home in March.
examples.ja: 私のおばあちゃんは、三月にグループホームに入所しました。

examples.en: I had an entrance test for a model agency today.
examples.ja: 今日はモデルエージェンシーの入所テストでした。

examples.en: Be sure to check the rules before your admission.
examples.ja: 入所の前に必ずルールをチェックしておいて下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>enter</kanji> a <kanji>facility</kanji>. So this is your <vocabulary>admission</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>entrance</vocabulary> into that facility. 

入所 is for entering facilities or institutions, often those with names ending in 所, like a 研究所 (research institute). It's also used in prison contexts. You might gain "admission" to prison for not doing your WaniKani reviews, for example, at least in countries ruled by Crabigators...
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: First, I'd like to make a presentation.
examples.ja: 始めに、プレゼンテーションをしたいと思います。

examples.en: Cut the cabbage first.
examples.ja: 始めにキャベツを切ります。

examples.en: I ate pasta on my first day of work this year.
examples.ja: 今年の仕事始めにはパスタを食べました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 始める means "to begin something"? 始め is its noun version and means "beginning," as in the start of an action or process. に marks a point in time. So 始めに means <vocabulary>in the beginning</vocabulary>. 

始めに can also mean <vocabulary>to begin with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to start with</vocabulary> when introducing an opening action, like 始めに、ウォーミングアップをしましょう (let's begin with some warm-up exercises).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi (look at all that hiragana!) but that's the reading you learned with the word 始める, so have no fear, you got it!

examples.en: Is this lettuce perhaps real?
examples.ja: このレタス、もしかして本物なの？

examples.en: I bought these Nike sneakers thinking they were real.
examples.ja: このナイキのスニーカー、本物だと思って買いました。

examples.en: Real rich people won't even complain about their duty of paying taxes.
examples.ja: 本物の金持ちは税金を払う義務について悪口なんて言わないよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>real</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>real thing</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>real deal</vocabulary>. 

If you learned 本 as <kanji>book</kanji> you can also think of this word as the "book thing." What is this book thing? Is it the real version of the book? Is it the real deal? If so, I'll pay you a million.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are on'yomi plus kun'yomi (kun'yomi is 物). You learned the reading of the kanji 本 and also the vocabulary reading of 物, so you should be able to read it.

examples.en: I got motion sickness.
examples.ja: 乗り物よいしちゃった。

examples.en: I loved riding things when I was little.
examples.ja: 小さいころ、ボクは乗り物に乗るのが大好きでした。

examples.en: I feel like old vehicles smell like time itself.
examples.ja: 古い乗り物には、時間のにおいがする気がするんだよね。

examples.en: In Japan, it is considered good manners to set your smartphone to silent mode and refrain from making calls on public transportation.
examples.ja: 日本では、公共の乗り物の中ではスマホはマナーモードにして通話はしないのがマナーです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 乗り has something to do with <kanji>riding</kanji> and that 物 is a <kanji>thing</kanji>. So what is a "riding thing?" Nowadays, at least, that would be a <vocabulary>vehicle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: There are lots of rich people's houses around here.
examples.ja: この辺は金持ちの家が多い。

examples.en: It's the kind of school where rich people would go to.
examples.ja: そこは金持ちが行くような学校だよ。

examples.en: I used to run small errands for a wealthy neighbor of mine to make money when I was young.
examples.ja: 若い頃、お金を稼ぐために、近所のお金持ちの人たちの使い走りをしていました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>hold</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are a <vocabulary>rich person</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Do you remember the word お金? This is the 金 in that word. The reading for 持ち is the も you learned with 持つ. So, combine the かね of お金 and the 持ち and you have the reading of this word. Note that just like お金, you'll often see this with the honorific prefix お in front of it as well.

examples.en: I know exactly how you feel.
examples.ja: あなたの気持ちはよく分かります。

examples.en: I've been feeling sick since I woke up in the morning.
examples.ja: 朝起きた時から気持ちわるいんです。

examples.en: Here’s a little something for you. This is just a small token of my appreciation. Go ahead, open it.
examples.ja: これ、つまらないものですが。ささやかな感謝の気持ちです。どうぞ、開けてみてください。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>energy</kanji> you <kanji>hold</kanji> in your body is your <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>s. It can take the form of all kinds of things. Good feelings, bad feelings, that "strange feeling."
reading_mnemonic: 気 is on'yomi and you learned that with the kanji. 持ち, though, is kun'yomi, which you learned with the word 持つ. One of those weird exception readings, but the ち on the end of 持ち is a clue that it uses the kun'yomi.

examples.en: This TV drama will be broadcast for the first time in ten years.
examples.ja: このドラマが放送されるのは、十年ぶりです。

examples.en: Are we really broadcasting this clip?
examples.ja: このクリップ、本当に放送するんですか？

examples.en: President Koichi's important announcement will be broadcast on television tonight.
examples.ja: コウイチ社長は今晩テレビで重大な決定を放送することになっている。

meaning_mnemonic:
You are going to <kanji>release</kanji> and <kanji>send</kanji> something out. Imagine this message going out through the sky to everyone around you. You are going <vocabulary>to broadcast something</vocabulary> to the world! 

The する is on there to make this noun a verb. Without the する it would be the noun "broadcast."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This tale is very long.
examples.ja: この物語はとても長いですよ。

examples.en: I'll read the Andersen story for you.
examples.ja: アンデルセン物語を読んであげましょう。

examples.en: There are many stories about yokai in various parts of Japan.
examples.ja: 妖怪にまつわる物語は、日本各地にたくさんあります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>language</kanji> about <kanji>thing</kanji>s. This is a confusing one. Just think of it more like someone talking about things, anything, really. Someone who just talks about things is someone who tells stories. So, this word means <vocabulary>tale</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>story</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary> (not the Tom Cruise one, though).
reading_mnemonic:
Both kanji take the kun'yomi here. For 物, that's もの, which you learned with the vocabulary 物. You learned the kun'yomi for 語 with the verb 語る, but here it becomes がたり because of rendaku, and the り is tucked inside the kanji.

Maybe you've already heard the word ものがたり too. It's in some film and book names. If you haven't, and you find this reading hard to remember, think of a story about an infamous <reading>Gatling</reading> (がたり) gun that wandered the land, mowing everything down in its path. It's a terrible legend, but what if it were true???

examples.en: Please don't argue about me!
examples.ja: わたしの事で争うのはよして！

examples.en: I am determined not to lose in a game where we compete for the champion belt.
examples.ja: チャンピオンベルトを争うゲームでは負けないって決めたんです。

examples.en: We've never argued, have we?
examples.ja: 私たちって言い争ったことないよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conflict</kanji> so the vocabulary means <vocabulary>to compete</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to argue</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to quarrel</vocabulary>. Your views conflict with someone else's so you're going to compete with them to see who's right.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You're starting <vocabulary>to compete</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to argue</vocabulary> with someone, who is yelling at you: "You <reading>are so</reading> (あらそ) stupid!". You might want to imagine this in an accent that gets you closer to the Japanese pronunciation.

examples.en: This is the first time I've gone to war in six months.
examples.ja: 戦争に行くのは半年ぶりです。

examples.en: I wish I were born in an era where there is no war.
examples.ja: 戦争のない時代に生まれたかったなあ。

examples.en: There are many things that we lost in the war, but we also have learned a lot from the war.
examples.ja: 戦争で失った事もたくさんあるけど、戦争から学んだ事もたくさんある。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>war</kanji> and <kanji>conflict</kanji>. Of course, conflict comes with war, so this word just means <vocabulary>war</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm really not in the mood for a competition right now.
examples.ja: 今は競争する気分じゃないんだけど。

examples.en: Today's breakfast is bread from yesterday's bread eating competition.
examples.ja: 今日の朝ごはんは、昨日のパン食い競争のパンです。

examples.en: These guys really need to chill out. They're always competing with each other and they both hate losing.
examples.ja: あいつら、もうちょっと落ち着いた方がいいよ。二人共負けず嫌いのくせに、いっつも二人で競争してるんだぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>compete</kanji> to the point of <kanji>conflict</kanji>, you know that this person / entity is your <vocabulary>competition</vocabulary>. Gotta beat out that competition. For example, in order to beat out the competition, WaniKani has a mascot that can eat every other small furry animal that the competition has for their mascot. Case closed.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't get along with my mother very much.
examples.ja: 母とは、あんまり仲が良くないんだよね。

examples.en: That couple has a really good relationship.
examples.ja: あのカップル、本当に仲が良いよね。

examples.en: I feel like my relationship with my team members deepened on that trip.
examples.ja: あの旅行でチームメンバーとの仲が深まった気がするよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading since it's a single kanji, all alone, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji, so you should be okay and have a great relationship with this word going forward.

examples.en: Could we meet up? I wouldn't be able to convey my message over an email.
examples.ja: これから会えますか？メールでは上手く伝えることができないんです。

examples.en: I told my teacher that I wanted to go to the bathroom.
examples.ja: 先生には、トイレに行きたいってちゃんと伝えてたんだよ。

examples.en: Please give your mother and father my regards.
examples.ja: お父様とお母様にも、よろしくお伝えくださいね。

examples.en: His eyes conveyed unease.
examples.ja: 彼の目が、不安を伝えていた。

examples.en: Air transmits sound to our ears.
examples.ja: 空気は、私たちの耳に音を伝えてくれます。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transmit</kanji>, but 伝える is mostly used for "transmitting" information, feelings, or messages to someone else. So it means <vocabulary>to convey</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to tell</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to pass down</vocabulary>.

In technical contexts, 伝える can also mean <vocabulary>to transmit</vocabulary>, in the sense that copper transmits heat or air transmits sound.
reading_mnemonic: You want <vocabulary>to convey</vocabulary> your knowledge to your apprentice, so you make them the best <reading>two</reading> <reading>ta</reading>cos (つた) you've ever made. They just wanted you <vocabulary>to tell</vocabulary> them the recipe, but you believe showing it is a better way <vocabulary>to pass down</vocabulary> that skill.

examples.en: I don't know what to talk about because Koichi and I have nothing in common.
examples.ja: コウイチとは共通点が全くないから、何を話せばいいか分からないよ。

examples.en: Culturally, Japan and China have many things in common.
examples.ja: 日本と中国は文化の共通点がたくさんあります。

examples.en: What do Koichi and I have in common? I guess we both love whiskey to death.
examples.ja: 俺とコウイチの共通点？死ぬほどウィスキーが好きって所くらいかな。

meaning_mnemonic: We <kanji>pass through</kanji> this <kanji>point</kanji> <kanji>together</kanji>. This point is our <vocabulary>common point</vocabulary>. It is where our ideas, philosophies, and bodies pass through each other.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Collaborative tasks with teammates are fun.
examples.ja: チームメイトとの共同作業は楽しいです。

examples.en: This is a co-working space for students to share.
examples.ja: ここは学生が共同で使うコーワーキングスペースです。

examples.en: He secretly used up our joint savings.
examples.ja: 彼は共同の貯金をこっそり使い果たしてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
If people work <kanji>together</kanji> on the <kanji>same</kanji> thing, they're working on a <vocabulary>joint</vocabulary> project. They're doing something <vocabulary>collaborative</vocabulary>.

共同 is used when two or more people or groups do something together with a <vocabulary>shared</vocabulary> purpose or responsibility. 共同作業 (collaborative work) means you share tasks with others, for example, and 共同生活 (shared living) means living together with someone, whether it's a partner or a roommate.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is a public bathroom! Not a place to do karaoke.
examples.ja: ここは公共トイレですよ！カラオケをする場所ではありません。

examples.en: Is there a public babysitter service?
examples.ja: 公共のベビーシッターのサービスがあるんですか？

examples.en: I used to volunteer at a public facility.
examples.ja: とある公共施設でボランティアをしていたことがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>public</kanji> comes <kanji>together</kanji> you have yourself a nice <vocabulary>community</vocabulary> made up of the <vocabulary>public</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Could you share this list?
examples.ja: このリスト、共有してもらえますか？

examples.en: You can finish tasks more quickly when you share them with your team.
examples.ja: タスクはチームと共有した方が早く終わるよ。

examples.en: The president's most important job is to share their vision.
examples.ja: 社長の一番の仕事は、ビジョンの共有です。

meaning_mnemonic: The things you <kanji>together</kanji> <kanji>have</kanji> are the things that are <vocabulary>shared</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you like WaniKani?
examples.ja: ワニカニのこと、好き？

examples.en: I love just staying home and doing nothing with someone I love.
examples.ja: 好きな人と家でゴロゴロするのが大好きです。

examples.en: I can't think of anything when you suddenly ask me what my favorite movie is like this.
examples.ja: こんな突然好きな映画を聞かれても、何も思いつかないですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 好 means <kanji>like</kanji> and this vocab word means the same thing: <vocabulary>like</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>!

This word is an adjective in Japanese, so a more literal translation is <vocabulary>likable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lovable</vocabulary>. Still, it usually sounds more natural to translate it as a verb in English.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Who do you <vocabulary>like</vocabulary> more than anyone? Your friend <reading>Sue</reading>. If you know someone named Sue, pretend you like her. If you don't, think of a famous person you know named Sue and use her, pretending you're good friends that like each other a lot.

examples.en: This key chain is a sign of our friendship.
examples.ja: このキーホルダーは、私たちの友好のシンボルです。

examples.en: Is the friendship between Japan and the United States strong?
examples.ja: 日本と米国の友好は強いですか？

examples.en: The man who lives in that house over there is friendly, but apparently he's secretly a yakuza member!
examples.ja: あそこの家のおじさん友好的だけど、実はヤクザの隠れメンバーらしいよ！

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>friend</kanji> you <kanji>like</kanji>, well, that's true <vocabulary>friendship</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to become an adult soon.
examples.ja: 早く大人に成りたいな。

examples.en: Did you know that tadpoles become frogs?
examples.ja: おたまじゃくしがカエルに成るって知ってた？

examples.en: He is a leader of a team that has become several hundred of people.
examples.ja: 彼は、数百人から成るチームのリーダーです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>become</kanji> so the vocab verb version would be <vocabulary>to become</vocabulary>.

While the kanji version is worth knowing, be aware that you'll usually see this verb written in hiragana.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You are starting <vocabulary>to become</vocabulary> something else. You're transforming, but you're not sure into what. First, you get fins... Uh oh, something in the water. Then, you gain a tail and rubbery skin... Hmm, something sea mammal-like. Oh, and then a huge horn sprouts out of your face. You are going to become a <reading>na</reading>rwhal (な).

examples.en: I hope the presentation tomorrow will be a success.
examples.ja: 明日のプレゼン、成功すると良いですね。

examples.en: I want to succeed this time.
examples.ja: 今回こそは成功したいんです。

examples.en: I created a curry-flavored toothpaste when I was told, "If you want to be successful in business you need to think outside the box."
examples.ja: 「ビジネスで成功したければ、型にはまらない考え方をしなさい」と言われて、カレー味の歯磨き粉を思いついたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>achievement</kanji>, you have probably gained plenty of <vocabulary>success</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Japan has a very large population of elderly people.
examples.ja: 日本は老人の人口がとても多いんですよ。

examples.en: Even a newborn baby will eventually become an old person.
examples.ja: 生まれたばかりの赤ちゃんだって、いずれは老人になります。

examples.en: Wow! That old man is such a hunky beefcake.
examples.ja: うわ！あの老人めちゃくちゃイケメンでマッチョなんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is an <vocabulary>old person</vocabulary> (or an <vocabulary>elderly person</vocabulary>). Don't call a person a 古い人, though. 古い is used for things, not people. Be nice, they're your elders.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Every <vocabulary>old person</vocabulary> has <reading>roe</reading> <reading>jean</reading>s(ろうじん), a special pair of jeans smeared with roe that they wear when they go out on the town. Some elderly people have cod roe jeans, some have salmon roe jeans… But tofugu roe jeans (adorned with the roe of the lesser spotted tofugu) are the most fashionable of all.

examples.en: I wonder where I'll rank this year.
examples.ja: 今年は何位だろう？

examples.en: That tennis player is ranked third in the world.
examples.ja: あのテニスプレイヤーは世界ランキング三位です。

examples.en: I came in first in the marathon, so my parents bought me a mountain bike.
examples.ja: マラソンで一位になったので、両親がマウンテンバイクを買ってくれた。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading, which you learned. This is probably because you'll see this word attached to other words, showing the rank of that thing.

examples.en: If you get first place, I'll make you curry every day for a week.
examples.ja: 一位になったら、一週間毎日カレーを作ってあげる。

examples.en: My sister took first place in the piano competition.
examples.ja: 妹がピアノコンクールで一位をとりました。

examples.en: Mom! I really aced that test! I ranked at the top of my class!
examples.ja: お母さん！僕、あのテストで滅茶苦茶良い点をとったんだよ！なんとクラスで一位だったんだ！

meaning_mnemonic: When you are number <kanji>one</kanji> in <kanji>rank</kanji>, you're in <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I got the first place in an academic test.
examples.ja: 学力テストで首位に立った。

examples.en: That woman is the world's top ranked tennis player.
examples.ja: あの女の人は世界ランキング首位のテニスプレーヤーです。

examples.en: That old person seemed to have zero interest in both teams' fight for first place.
examples.ja: その老人は、両チームの首位争いには全く興味が無いようだった。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're at <kanji>neck</kanji> <kanji>rank</kanji> you're in <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "neck and neck" when two people in a race are both super close to first place? Just remember that and you'll never forget this word.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned this reading for 首 when you learned 部首, and the reading for 位 is the one you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I like a guy with a low voice.
examples.ja: 低い声の男の人が好きです。

examples.en: I am already so tired of men like you who have little pride.
examples.ja: あんたみたいにプライドが低すぎる男はもうウンザリよ。

examples.en: All of my husband's family members are short.
examples.ja: 夫の家族は皆、背が低いんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>low</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>low</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You look down and very <vocabulary>low</vocabulary> to the ground is a man, looking up at you. Your friend is there too, but you don't know this little man. Your friend says "<reading>He coo'</reading>, he coo," referring to the low to the ground man.

examples.en: That drama show was the worst!
examples.ja: あのドラマ、最低だった！

examples.en: I got the worst score at the exam this time.
examples.ja: 今回のテストは、今までで最低の点だった。

examples.en: The lowest temperature tomorrow will be below zero degrees.
examples.ja: 明日の最低気温は０度を下回るでしょう。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>low</kanji> is <vocabulary>the lowest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the minimum</vocabulary>. It's also what you call something when you think it's <vocabulary>the worst</vocabulary> or just plain <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary>. Try yelling this out when you're disgusted about someone or something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: A first time massage would be 8000 yen.
examples.ja: マッサージ初回は八千円です。

examples.en: Please bring your smartphone to the first lesson.
examples.ja: 初回のレッスンにはスマホを持ってきて下さいね。

examples.en: Oh, is this your first time attending our Japanese language club? Okay everyone, he’s a newbie, so let’s go easy on him.
examples.ja: えっ、君が日本語学習クラブに参加するのは今回が初回なんだ？よし、みんな。彼は初心者だから手加減してあげようぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> of something you'll do several or many <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>the first time</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I was doing well at first, but I got exhausted an hour later.
examples.ja: 最初は元気だったんですが、１時間後にはヘトヘトでした。

examples.en: The first class at junior high school was English.
examples.ja: 中学校の最初のクラスは英語でした。

examples.en: When I first came to Japan, I didn't know that the toilet had a bidet.
examples.ja: 日本に来た最初の頃はトイレにビデが付いてるなんて知らなかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>first</kanji> thing is <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary> thing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Why don't we try a different approach?
examples.ja: 別のアプローチをしてみない？

examples.en: It was another man who I went on a date with yesterday.
examples.ja: 昨日デートに行ったのは別の男です。

examples.en: My sister was born from another mother.
examples.ja: 姉は私とは別の母から生まれた子です。

meaning_mnemonic: The の is there to indicate that it is the difference of something. For example this is like saying "the <vocabulary>separate</vocabulary> ______" or "the <vocabulary>different</vocabulary> _____" or "<vocabulary>another</vocabulary> ______". 別 by itself just means separate, different, or another.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned. Move on to a 別の漢字, ok?

examples.en: Could you use separate Tupperware for the broccoli and stew?
examples.ja: ブロッコリーとシチューのタッパーは別にしてもらえますか？

examples.en: As long as there's coffee, I wouldn't mind going to any cafe in particular.
examples.ja: 別にコーヒーがあればどこのカフェでもいいよ。

examples.en: "Is your mother doing okay?" "Yeah. Nothing's changed in particular."
examples.ja: 「お母さん元気にしてる？」「うん。別に変わりないよ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
If someone asks if you want a <kanji>separate</kanji> knee (に), you'll say <vocabulary>not particularly</vocabulary>. I mean, you've never thought about it, but do you really need more knees? <vocabulary>Not really</vocabulary>...

In this first meaning, 別に is often used on its own, or with a negative verb or adjective, as in 別に長くない (not particularly long).

However, when 別に is used with a positive verb, it often simply means <vocabulary>separately</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>in addition to</vocabulary>. After all, when you have to do something separately, you have to do it in addition to something else. Like learning this meaning in addition to the first one. What a chore!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Well done!

examples.en: Koichi has become a changed man ever since he quit drinking.
examples.ja: コウイチはお酒をやめてから、すっかり別人になったね。

examples.en: I thought it was my friend Koichi when I called out to him, but it was a different person.
examples.ja: 友人のコウイチだと思って声をかけたら、別人だった。

examples.en: Koichi used to diss AKB48 pretty often, but now he's a crazed AKB48 fan. It’s as though he's a different person.
examples.ja: コウイチは昔はAKB48をよくディスっていたのに、今はすっかり大ファンになっちまった。まるで別人のようだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>separate</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is someone who is different from who they were before. I saw you a year ago and you were someone else. Now you're a <vocabulary>different person</vocabulary>, in a good way! You're a <vocabulary>changed man</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My schedule doesn't really fit my friend's, so we are going to Hawaii separately.
examples.ja: 友人とのスケジュールが合わないのでハワイまで別々に行きます。

examples.en: Put the potatoes and celery out separately.
examples.ja: ジャガイモとセロリは別々に入れておいてください。

examples.en: "Now do we really have to go our separate ways?" "Yup, but I believe we'll see each other again soon."
examples.ja: 「私達、本当に別々の道を進まなきゃいけないの？」「ああ。でもまたすぐ会えるさ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
When you say <kanji>separate</kanji> <kanji>separate</kanji>, you're putting things off into their own areas. So 別々 means <vocabulary>separate</vocabulary>. 

Note that this word is typically used in reference to multiple separate items, as opposed to 別の, which refers to a single separate or different thing. It's also used a lot as an adverb with the particle に to mean "separately."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the べつ reading you know, twice.

examples.en: This is a special necklace.
examples.ja: これは特別なネックレスなんです。

examples.en: Was there a special meeting or something that the president bothered to come all the way to the office for?
examples.ja: 社長がわざわざオフィスに来たなんて何か特別なミーティングでもあったんですか？

examples.en: Is there a special edition of this car?
examples.ja: この車の特別仕様の在庫はありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>special</kanji> and <kanji>separate</kanji> from the rest is, well, <vocabulary>special</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My bike's brakes don't work.
examples.ja: 自転車のブレーキが利かない。

examples.en: My child is thoughtful.
examples.ja: うちの子、気が利くんですよ。

examples.en: Koichi is a pretty flexible man.
examples.ja: コウイチは中々融通の利く男だ。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the kanji means <kanji>profit</kanji>. When you make it into a verb, though, it means <vocabulary>to work well</vocabulary>. If you think about it, when something works well it makes you a profit.
reading_mnemonic: What works so well? Your special <reading>key</reading> (き) that can unlock anyone and anything's potential. Imagine putting it into a key slot in someone's back. Someone who's a good for nothing can't-do-anything is now an effective member of society! Go around using your key on other non-effective things and show them that anything is possible!

examples.en: This app is really handy, right?
examples.ja: このアプリ、すごく便利だよね。

examples.en: If you know of any useful items, please let me know.
examples.ja: 便利なアイテムを知っていたらぜひ教えて下さい。

examples.en: Life is getting more convenient day after day.
examples.ja: 生活は日に日に便利になっていく。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>profit</kanji> from your <kanji>convenience</kanji>, that means you have something very <vocabulary>convenient</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>handy</vocabulary>. Remember, you can profit in other ways besides money. This convenience could be giving you a profit in happiness or extra time as well. All these things are very handy to have.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Hey, are you really thinking you can become a company president without making any efforts?
examples.ja: あんた、努力しないで社長になれるとでも思ってんの？

examples.en: Even winning the lottery requires a certain amount of effort, alright?
examples.ja: 宝くじを当てるのだって、それなりの努力が必要なんだよ！

examples.en: Even if you work hard, if you don't have results, there isn't a point to it.
examples.ja: 努力しても、結果が出なくては意味が無い。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>toil</kanji> and use your <kanji>strength</kanji>. Ugh! How difficult. You really put in a <vocabulary>great effort</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The labor hours are very long at this job.
examples.ja: この仕事、労働時間がすごく長いんです。

examples.en: Isn't golfing with clients considered holiday work?
examples.ja: クライアントとのゴルフは休日労働じゃないんですか？

examples.en: Intense physical labor is hard for people at this age.
examples.ja: この歳で激しい肉体労働はキツいです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>labor</kanji> <kanji>work</kanji> is when you're doing work with your body, right? That's <vocabulary>manual labor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My life was full of hardships until I came across WaniKani.
examples.ja: ワニカニに出会うまでは、おれの人生は苦労ばかりだった。

examples.en: I went through hardship to finally get Koichi's autograph.
examples.ja: このコウイチのサイン、苦労してやっと手に入れたんだよ。

examples.en: In my bathtub, the position of the shower is fixed, so it is quite difficult to wash and rinse.
examples.ja: うちのお風呂って、シャワーの位置が固定されちゃってるから、バスタブを洗って流すときにかなり苦労するんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Suffering</kanji> and <kanji>labor</kanji>. Sounds like the kind of thing these soft hands wouldn't want to deal with. These are <vocabulary>hardships</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>troubles</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have too much of this with kanji anymore!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What does president Koichi think about the shortage of workers in Japan?
examples.ja: コウイチ社長は、日本の労働者不足についてどうお考えなんですか？

examples.en: Workers like us are supporting this country.
examples.ja: 私たちのような労働者たちがこの国を支えてるんですよ。

examples.en: If you are a president, please try to protect the rights of workers.
examples.ja: 社長という立場なら、労働者の権利を守ってくださいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who does <kanji>labor</kanji> for <kanji>work</kanji> is a <vocabulary>laborer</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Even a bug's life is an important life.
examples.ja: 虫の命だって、大切な命なんだよ。

examples.en: This figure is the second most important thing, after my life.
examples.ja: このフィギュアは命の次に大切なんです。

examples.en: God, please. Save this child's life in exchange for my life.
examples.ja: 神様、お願いです。私の命と引き換えに、この子の命を救ってください。

meaning_mnemonic: A vocab made from a single kanji all alone usually keeps at least one of the meanings of its kanji parent. In this case, that's <vocabulary>life</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  

The Book of <reading>Enoch</reading> (いのち) has passed down your fate and told you how to use your <vocabulary>life</vocabulary>. You must read the book of Enoch and find out what you're supposed to do.

examples.en: It's destiny that I met you here on that day.
examples.ja: あの日、ここであなたと会えたのは運命ですよ。

examples.en: It was meant to be like that.
examples.ja: そういう運命だったんだよ。

examples.en: Rest in peace iPhone. I just dropped it in a toilet filled with more than just water. Maybe this was just fate but I am so sad right now.
examples.ja: iPhoneさん天国行き。用を足した後のトイレに落としちゃいました。まぁ、これがiPhoneさんの運命だったのかもしれないけどさ。でも、猛烈に悲しいぜよ...。

meaning_mnemonic: Everyone has to <kanji>carry</kanji> their <kanji>fate</kanji>. So what is the thing you're carrying? It's your <vocabulary>fate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is a command from King Koichi.
examples.ja: これは、コウイチ王からの命令です。

examples.en: Why do I have to be told to pick up the phone?
examples.ja: 何であなたに「電話に出ろ」と命令されなければいけないんですか？

examples.en: "C’mon! What are you waiting for? Run!" "Don’t order me around!"
examples.ja: 「ほら！何をダラダラ待ってるの? 走って！」「俺に命令するんじゃねぇよ！」

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>fate</kanji> <kanji>orders</kanji> are the orders you get from above. You are <vocabulary>order</vocabulary>ed and <vocabulary>command</vocabulary>ed to carry out said orders.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Today, I jogged at the seashore.
examples.ja: 今日は海岸をジョギングしました。

examples.en: I saw yachts and surfers from the coast.
examples.ja: 海岸からはヨットやサーファーが見えました。

examples.en: I want to go to a stylish cafe along the coastline this Sunday.
examples.ja: 今週の日曜日は海岸線沿いのお洒落なカフェに行きたいな。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ocean</kanji>/<kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>coast</kanji> is the <vocabulary>seashore</vocabulary>. Then again, it could also be the <vocabulary>coast</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let me go!
examples.ja: 放せよ！

examples.en: Thirty minutes later, Koichi finally released my hand.
examples.ja: 三十分後、コウイチはついに私の手を放した。

examples.en: Is there a dog park or similar place around here where I can let my dog run free?
examples.ja: この辺りに、犬を放してあそばせられるドッグランみたいなとこはありますか？

examples.en: Every time I let Fugu loose in the sea, he swims off and when I call him he doesn't listen. What should I do to teach him to not run away?
examples.ja: フグを海に放すといつも、泳いで逃げちゃって、私が呼んでも知らんぷりするの。どうすれば逃げないように教えることができるのかしら。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>release</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to release</vocabulary>, as in <vocabulary>to set free</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to let something go</vocabulary>.

放す often suggests that you've released something in a way that gives it freedom to move or go where it wants. Think of letting your dog run in the field — it's not just that you let go of the leash, but that the dog is now free to run around as it pleases.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need <vocabulary>to release</vocabulary> your pet <reading>花</reading> (はな). It's a monstrous, carnivorous 花 that you keep in a cage in your backyard. You think it's super cute, but your neighbors say it scares them, so you need <vocabulary>to set free</vocabulary> your beloved 花. Hopefully it doesn't eat anyone on its way back to the wild.

meanings: To Open Something To The Public

examples.en: We open our office up into a bar at night.
examples.ja: 夜はオフィスをバーとして開放しています。

examples.en: In summer, this pool is also open to the public.
examples.ja: 夏はこのプールも公共に開放されます。

examples.en: Once a month, the museum is open to citizens for free.
examples.ja: 月に一回、美術館が市民に無料開放されます。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>open</kanji> then <kanji>release</kanji>, say, a door, you're opening it up for everyone to come in. That's why it means <vocabulary>to open something up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to throw something open</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This place used to be a mountain a long time ago.
examples.ja: ここは昔、山だったんだよ。

examples.en: Koichi is just an old friend.
examples.ja: コウイチはただの昔の友人です。

examples.en: I once kissed the TV screen a long time ago.
examples.ja: 昔、一回だけ、テレビ画面にキスしたことがあるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is a good way to start stories, by the way: 昔々に… (Long, long ago).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. むかし sounds like a kun'yomi reading, doesn't it? It's so long.

examples.en: If you stand over here, you will get good Wi-Fi signal.
examples.ja: ここに立つとWi-Fiの電波がよく入りますよ。

examples.en: My mother is worried about radio waves and does not use the microwave.
examples.ja: 母は電波が心配で電子レンジを使わない。

examples.en: Sorry, you sound kind of choppy. It seems like I’ve got bad reception here.
examples.ja: ごめん、よく聞こえないよ。ここは電波が悪いみたい。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> is a wave of electricity going through the air. There are many words you can use to describe this, but the easiest one is <vocabulary>reception</vocabulary> (like the reception on your phone, for example).

Other more technical meanings are <vocabulary>radio wave</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>electromagnetic waves</vocabulary>. Which one you like is up to you, but reception is going to be the most common meaning on the street. Luckily people in Japan don't have AT&T, otherwise you'd hear this word a lot more…
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The は from 波 rendakus to ぱ, so be careful. Maybe it's your <reading>pa</reading> who has bad reception every time you try to call him?

examples.en: Did you pour olive oil in my coke by any chance?
examples.ja: もしかして、私のコーラにオリーブオイル注いだ？

examples.en: When I become a high school student, I want to pour all of my energy into my part-time job.
examples.ja: 高校生になったらアルバイトに全力を注ぎたいです。

examples.en: Can you pour a little more wine?
examples.ja: もう少しワインを注いでいただけますか？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pour</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pour</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You are going <vocabulary>to pour</vocabulary> some <reading>sauce</reading> (そそ).

examples.en: Today, I got a warning from my teacher.
examples.ja: 今日、先生に注意されちゃったよ。

examples.en: Be careful of cars when you go for a run.
examples.ja: ランニングに行く時は車に注意してね。

examples.en: I'm worried that he might be heading in a bad direction. I cautioned him, but he won't listen at all.
examples.ja: 私は彼が悪い方向に進んでるんじゃないかと心配しているのよ。注意したんだけど、全く聞かないの。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>pour</kanji> your <kanji>ideas</kanji> into something, you're thinking a lot about it. You're paying close <vocabulary>attention</vocabulary> and using <vocabulary>caution</vocabulary>. You'll see this on a lot of <vocabulary>warning</vocabulary> signs marking dangerous things in Japan, so be sure to pay attention to them!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't really understand how to order at Starbucks.
examples.ja: スタバの注文の仕方がよく分からないんだけど。

examples.en: You can order this dress online.
examples.ja: このドレス、ネットで注文できるよ。

examples.en: That’s an unreasonable request but we don’t have a choice.
examples.ja: それは無理な注文だが、やるっきゃない。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>pour</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> onto a form. You're filling out this form to <vocabulary>order</vocabulary> something new for yourself. It's a formal <vocabulary>request</vocabulary> to get this new thing (imagine it being something you're excited about ordering right now, and imagine yourself ordering it by pouring writing onto an order form).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This work should be done by five if everyone concentrates.
examples.ja: みんなが集中すればこの仕事は五時までに終わるはずだよ。

examples.en: Focus until class is over!
examples.ja: クラスが終わるまで集中して！

examples.en: I can't concentrate on reading books when I'm around people.
examples.ja: 人の前だと集中して本が読めないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>collect</kanji> and focus in on the <kanji>middle</kanji>. Really zoom in on it. When you do this, you're concentrating on this spot, thus making the meaning of this word <vocabulary>to concentrate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to focus</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I was born and raised in Tokyo.
examples.ja: わたしは東京で生まれ育ちました。

examples.en: This cactus is growing well.
examples.ja: このサボテン、元気に育ってるね。

examples.en: Love grew between the dog and Koichi.
examples.ja: いつの間にかその犬とコウイチの間には愛が育ちました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>raise</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be raised</vocabulary>. 

P.S. This word is for when you are being raised, not when you are doing the raising of someone. That's <vocabulary>育てる</vocabulary>. You'll learn it later.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you were raised, you were raised completely on <reading>soda</reading> (そだ). That's all you drank. No water, no juice... just tons and tons of soda. Imagine this.

examples.en: Today, we are going to the education center.
examples.ja: 今日は教育センターに行きます。

examples.en: In Japan, you're obligated to receive elementary school education and junior high school education.
examples.ja: 日本では、小学校教育と中学校教育を受けなければなりません。

examples.en: Do you remember who said, "It is a thousand times better to have common sense without education than education without common sense?"
examples.ja: 「教育があって常識がないよりも、教育がなくて常識がある方がはるかによい。」って誰の言葉だっけ？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Teach</kanji> and <kanji>nurture</kanji>. That's what your <vocabulary>education</vocabulary> is supposed to do.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I volunteered for a year to pick up trash on the beach.
examples.ja: 海岸でゴミを拾うボランティアを一年間やりました。

examples.en: I just picked up a 500 yen coin on the sidewalk.
examples.ja: さっき歩道で五百円玉を拾いました。

examples.en: There was an abandoned sofa on the roadside and it looked still usable, so I picked it up.
examples.ja: 道端にソファを捨ててあったんだけど、まだ使えそうだったから、拾ってきたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pick up</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pick something up</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done!

examples.en: The compass arrow is pointing at the direction of North.
examples.ja: コンパスの矢が北の方向を指しています。

examples.en: In Japan, it's rude to point at people with your finger.
examples.ja: 人を指で指すのは、日本では失礼です。

examples.en: I haven't done my homework... What if the teacher points at me?
examples.ja: 宿題やってないよ、、。先生に指されたらどうしよう。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>finger</kanji>. So, if you "to finger" something, what are you doing? You're pointing. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to point</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You are pointing at something in fear. It is a <reading>saw</reading> (さ). Thing is, you're pointing at this saw with a missing finger. It just cut off your finger and you're freaking out, trying to point with a bloody non-finger.

examples.en: You have such beautiful fingers.
examples.ja: 指がきれいですね。

examples.en: Why do we have five fingers and also five toes?
examples.ja: なんで手の指も足の指も五本なんだろう？

examples.en: I just had a sudden pain in my middle finger.
examples.ja: 突然中指が痛くなったんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. The only difference is that this word can mean <vocabulary>finger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>toe</vocabulary>. What are toes but small, walking fingers?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

What do you use your <vocabulary>finger</vocabulary> for the most? For pointing, of course! Imagine going up to people and saying, "What will <reading>you be</reading> (ゆび) when you grow up?" Point your finger at the next person, "What will you be?" Keep going until you're just saying, "You be? You be?" with your finger out.

examples.en: The meeting place was designated by the client.
examples.ja: ミーティングの場所は、お客さまが指定しました。

examples.en: May I assign my own flight?
examples.ja: 自分でフライトを指定してもいいですか？

examples.en: This painting is designated as a national treasure in Japan.
examples.ja: この絵は日本に国宝に指定されてます。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>determine</kanji> and use your <kanji>finger</kanji> to point at someone or something, you're going <vocabulary>to appoint</vocabulary> them. Just imagine yourself determining who's the best for the job then pointing with your finger. That is who you will appoint. The する on the end makes it a verb, so <vocabulary>指定</vocabulary> would be "appointment" or "designation" or something along those lines. Cool how する works.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It's important to check the size before buying clothes.
examples.ja: 洋服を買う前にサイズをチェックをするのは大切です。

examples.en: Should I wear Japanese clothes for today's date? Or should I wear regular clothes?
examples.ja: 今日のデートは和服にしようかな？洋服にしようかな？

examples.en: You should get dressed really quickly or you’ll be late for school.
examples.ja: 早く洋服を着ないと、学校に遅れるわよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Western style</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> is just <vocabulary>Western clothing</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>Western style clothes</vocabulary>). But nowadays, because Japanese people wear Western clothing all the time, we use it to just mean <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary>. We're talking things that aren't kimonos, etc.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This house has three small western style rooms.
examples.ja: この家には小さな洋室が三つあります。

examples.en: There are beds and desks in the western style room.
examples.ja: 洋室にはベッドとデスクがあります。

examples.en: My room is a six-tatami-sized, western style room, with my favorite shade of light blue on the walls.
examples.ja: 私の部屋は六畳の洋室で、壁の色は私の好きな水色です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>Western style</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> is a <vocabulary>Western style room</vocabulary>. We're talking something that's not a tatami mat filled room. Good to know this word if you're staying in hotels or ryokans and prefer not to sleep on a futon, etc.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you think the gods exist somewhere?
examples.ja: 神はどこかにいると思いますか？

examples.en: I wish there were a call center where I could consult with God.
examples.ja: 神に相談できるコールセンターがあったら良いのに。

examples.en: God may be able to walk on water, but I can swim in the meadow.
examples.ja: 神様は水の上を歩けるかもしれないけど、俺は草地の上を泳ぐことができるんだぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Do you know the word "Kamikaze"? Also, do you remember the word 風 from a previous level? Kamikaze means "divine winds" or "godly winds." If you know the word "Kamikaze" you can apply it to this single word, that means "god" or "gods." Use your prior knowledge to remember this reading.

examples.en: Shinto doesn't really have specific teachings.
examples.ja: 神道には特に教えがないんですよ。

examples.en: Koichi just kept talking about Shinto.
examples.ja: コウイチは、ひたすら神道について語った。

examples.en: Why doesn’t Shinto have an absolute God?
examples.ja: どうして神道には絶対的な神がいないのですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji>/<kanji>road</kanji> of the <kanji>god</kanji>(s) is, as you can probably guess, a big Japanese religion. There's two, and I'll give you a hint, this one isn't Buddhism (that would probably have the kanji for Buddha in it, no?). So what's the other big one? It's <vocabulary>Shinto</vocabulary>. If you're having trouble remembering this because you've never heard of it before, skip to the reading. The reading will help.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit wonky. 神 should be no problem. 道 on the other hand is almost the one you learned (どう) but now it's とう for some reason. Perhaps the gods took away the dakuten to make it とう, who knows. All I know is that it's best not to question said gods. If you already know of Shinto in English, though, this reading should be really easy. If you don't, perhaps you can use this reading to help you to remember Shinto the religion.

examples.en: There are lots of small shrines around here.
examples.ja: この辺は小さい神社が多いですね。

examples.en: Have you ever drawn a fortune slip at a shrine?
examples.ja: 神社でおみくじを引いたことはありますか？

examples.en: Many influencers are taking selfies at shrines these days.
examples.ja: 最近は神社で自撮りするインフルエンサーが多いんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>God</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji>... think of this as "what 'company' does the god's work?" Well, the answer to that is a shrine, probably. In this case a <vocabulary>Shinto shrine</vocabulary> because of the しん in 神.
reading_mnemonic: But wait! 神 is read じん in this word for some reason. Darn those gods, always messing around, adding dakuten. Maybe this will help, though: Imagine yourself at a Shinto shrine. You are praying to the gods, asking for food. Out from the sky rains <reading>ginger</reading> (じんじゃ). You are pelted with it and not sure if you should be happy or upset.

examples.en: I sent a LINE message to Koichi and he replied to me in a second lol.
examples.ja: コウイチにラインしたら秒で返事きたw

examples.en: When I go to bed, I usually fall asleep in three seconds.
examples.ja: 大体いつも、ふとんに入ったら三秒でねてる。

examples.en: Your pronunciation can reach native-level in just twelve seconds.
examples.ja: あなたの発音をたったの十二秒でネイティブレベルにしてみせますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well - that is the unit of time, <vocabulary>second</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji. It's presumably because it's usually attached to other things, like numbers, making it act more like a jukugo word would. Anyway, you should only need a <vocabulary>second</vocabulary> to learn this reading, since you should already know it.

examples.en: I can't accept such a high-class gift.
examples.ja: こんな高級なプレゼントもらえません。

examples.en: This is a famous high-end tea in China.
examples.ja: これは中国で有名な高級茶なんですよ。

examples.en: That luxury restaurant is exclusive for VIPs, and to enter, you'll need an invitation or a referral.
examples.ja: あの高級レストランはVIP専用で、入店には招待状か紹介状が必要なんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>grade</kanji> item is really just a <vocabulary>high grade</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>high-class</vocabulary> item.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm moving to the intermediate level class from the beginner level class next week.
examples.ja: 来週、初級から中級にレベルが上がります。

examples.en: This course is divided into three levels: beginner, intermediate and advanced.
examples.ja: このコースは、初級、中級、上級の三つのレベルに分かれています。

examples.en: My Japanese is still at an elementary level, but I’m working hard at it.
examples.ja: 私の日本語はまだ初級レベルですが、一生懸命勉強しています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> <kanji>level</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>beginner level</vocabulary>. Compare this to 中級 and 上級 (vocab from this level) to get a fuller understanding.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What kind of level is an intermediate level?
examples.ja: 中級とは、どういったレベルですか？

examples.en: I want to join the intermediate Japanese class.
examples.ja: 中級の日本語クラスに入りたいんです。

examples.en: There are only a few people who are intermediate English speakers at this company.
examples.ja: この会社には英語が中級の人たちは少ない。

meaning_mnemonic: Something at the <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>level</kanji> or <kanji>grade</kanji> is at an <vocabulary>intermediate level</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I can't follow the advanced level class.
examples.ja: どうしても上級クラスについていけません。

examples.en: Koichi is a senior student at my school.
examples.ja: コウイチは私の学校の上級生です。

examples.en: Some non-native speakers speak English at a native or advanced level, while others do not.
examples.ja: 英語が母国語でない人で、ネイティブレベルや上級の英語を話す人もいれば、そうでない人もいます。

meaning_mnemonic: When you are at an <kanji>above</kanji> <kanji>level</kanji>, you are at an <vocabulary>advanced level</vocabulary>. This is referring to things like proficiency in Japanese, or things like that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am not good at following women.
examples.ja: 女の人を追うのが下手なんですよ。

examples.en: Koichi is always following the latest fashion trends.
examples.ja: コウイチは、いつも最新のファッショントレンドを追っている。

examples.en: I will keep following my dreams, no matter how hard it gets.
examples.ja: どんなに大変でも、私は自分の夢を追い続けるつもりなの。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>follow</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to follow</vocabulary> (it's also <vocabulary>to chase</vocabulary>, because when you follow something you are chasing it too).
reading_mnemonic: You've learned this reading already, so you should know how to read this word!

examples.en: Dad always loses his battles with Mom.
examples.ja: 父は、いつも母との戦いに負ける。

examples.en: I don't like conflicts.
examples.ja: 戦いはきらいです。

examples.en: Stop fighting unnecessary battles!
examples.ja: ムダな戦いはやめろ！

examples.en: He went straight for a Big Mac after the bloody fight.
examples.ja: 彼は血みどろの戦いの後、そのままビッグマックを食べに行った。

meaning_mnemonic: Don't let this word confuse you. It may end in い, but it's not an adjective, it's a noun. There are no rules in war, after all. This word describes what happens in <kanji>war</kanji>. Those things are <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>fight</vocabulary>s, and <vocabulary>conflict</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In a fierce <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary>, there's always a lot of collateral damage. One of the things that gets destroyed is your car. But you can't do anything about it, it's battle time! So you wave goodbye to your car saying, "<reading>Ta-ta ca</reading>r (たたか)!" as you punch some jerk in the face.

examples.en: I planned some tactics for the game tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日のゲームのための作戦を立てました。

examples.en: Our strategy has been leaked to the spies.
examples.ja: 私たちの作戦はスパイに知られてしまった。

examples.en: The proposal did not go according to the strategy.
examples.ja: プロポーズは作戦通りにはいかなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>make</kanji> <kanji>war</kanji>, you're building it up like you'd build a building. You have to make <vocabulary>strategy</vocabulary>, you have to plan, you have to come up with awesome <vocabulary>tactics</vocabulary> for your <vocabulary>operation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Why is there a tank running through such a place?
examples.ja: なんでこんな所を戦車が走ってるんだろう？

examples.en: Have you ever pumped up a tank's tires?
examples.ja: 戦車のタイヤに空気を入れたことはありますか？

examples.en: Don't play around the tank!
examples.ja: 戦車の周りで遊んじゃダメだよ！

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>war</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji> is probably a little more dangerous than the Honda you drive. No, a war car is a <vocabulary>tank</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Sorry. I can't pick up the phone right now because I'm on the battlefield.
examples.ja: すみません。今、戦場にいるので電話に出られないんです。

examples.en: The office today was like a yakuza battlefield.
examples.ja: 今日のオフィスはヤクザの戦場のようだった。

examples.en: Koichi is a dependable guy. He would never let us down even if we were on a battlefield.
examples.ja: コウイチは頼れるやつだ。たとえ戦場にいたとしても、俺達を決して見捨てやしないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>war</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is the <vocabulary>battlefield</vocabulary>. That's where the wars are fought, anyways.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I am not planning to compete with you over chess.
examples.ja: あなたとチェスで競うつもりはないです。

examples.en: I don't really like competing with people.
examples.ja: 人と競うのはあまり好きじゃないんですよね。

examples.en: It's good to have someone to compete with.
examples.ja: 競う相手がいるのは良いことだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>compete</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to compete</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You really have <vocabulary>to compete</vocabulary> for <reading>key so</reading>ap (きそ). These days everyone wants their keys as clean as possible, and the special key soap they use is pretty hard to come by. Whenever it's in stock again people try to compete over it. Just imagine all those shoppers fighting over some key soap…

examples.en: I think that idea is very good!
examples.ja: そのアイディアすごい良いですね！

examples.en: You say you're getting along well as you fight, right?
examples.ja: ケンカするほど仲が良いって言うだろ？

examples.en: It's a good idea, but we don't have enough money to do it.
examples.ja: 良い考えだけど、実際それをするには資金が足りないんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>good</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>good</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:

A <vocabulary>good</vocabulary> way to pass the time is with a <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ). But it better be a good yo-yo. A bad one will just fall apart.

Note that よい is a more formal or literary way of saying "good," the more common one being いい. To distinguish the different readings, the latter version is usually written in just kana too!

examples.en: I don't have any plans today in particular.
examples.ja: 今日は特に予定ないですよ。

examples.en: This melon is especially hard. It's like a bowling ball.
examples.ja: このメロンは特にかたいですね。まるでボーリングの玉のようだ。

examples.en: "What would you like for supper?" "Anything is fine. I’m not especially picky."
examples.ja: 「お夕飯は何が食べたい？」「何でもいいよ。特にこだわりはないよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: Something is towards (に) <kanji>special</kanji>. That thing is <vocabulary>especially</vocabulary> special, wouldn't you say?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same reading you learned for this kanji.

examples.en: Not having a car around here is really inconvenient.
examples.ja: この辺りでは、車を持っていないとかなり不便ですよ。

examples.en: If there is any inconvenience, let the front desk know immediately.
examples.ja: もし不便なことがあればすぐにフロントデスクに言ってくださいね。

examples.en: Welcome to my man cave. Beers are in the refrigerator. It may be a bit inconvenient for you, but you’ve got to go outside to smoke.
examples.ja: 俺の隠れ家へようこそ。ビールは冷蔵庫に入ってるぜ。ちょっと不便かもしれねぇが、煙草は外で吸ってくれよな。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>convenience</kanji> is <vocabulary>inconvenient</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh snap. I came to school in toilet sandals!
examples.ja: やばい。便所サンダルで学校に来ちゃった！

examples.en: I'm going to a convenience store bathroom real quick.
examples.ja: ちょっとコンビニの便所行ってくるわ。

examples.en: The word <ja>便所</ja> sounds a bit vulgar.
examples.ja: 「便所」っていう言葉はちょっと下品ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
*Ahem.* This is the <kanji>convenience</kanji> <kanji>facility</kanji>. What place above all others should be convenient to get to? You know, just in case? That would be the <vocabulary>restroom</vocabulary>. You might also call it the <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>toilet</vocabulary>, the lavatory, or the facilities.

This word is casual and can often sound gruff, so you won't normally see it on official signs or hear it in polite conversation. It's worth knowing so you can understand it in casual speaking and writing though.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: Ants are very hard working bugs.
examples.ja: アリは、よく働く虫だね。

examples.en: I want to work in Japan someday.
examples.ja: いつか日本で働きたいんです。

examples.en: Why do I have to work on holidays?
examples.ja: なんで休日も働かなきゃいけないの？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>work</kanji>, and the verb version means <vocabulary>to work</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to labor</vocabulary>, and sometimes <vocabulary>to commit</vocabulary> (a crime).
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are as mad as a <reading>hatter</reading> you'll need <vocabulary>to work</vocabulary> very hard to regain your sanity. You know The Hatter from Alice in Wonderland? Imagine how hard he would have to work to be considered "normal".

examples.en: Do you have any opinions about this plan?
examples.ja: このプランについて、意見はありますか？

examples.en: I can't help caring about the opinions of people I'm close to.
examples.ja: 仲のいい人の意見は、やっぱり気になります。

examples.en: This is just my personal opinion, but I sometimes think that Japan is a really weird country.
examples.ja: これは俺の個人的な意見なんだけど、たまに日本は本当に変わった国だなぁと思うんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>idea</kanji> you <kanji>see</kanji> in your head is your <vocabulary>opinion</vocabulary>. As the dude once said... "That's just, like, your 意見, man."
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is all on'yomi, meaning 意 is just fine. 見's on'yomi (けん) is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji because it's so much less useful, but you do have to know it here. You've seen it with 発見 a couple levels ago, so that should help. Still, here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

In this case, just think about how <reading>Ken</reading> the samurai has an <vocabulary>opinion</vocabulary> on everything. Ken is such a know-it-all, and you're better off agreeing with his opinions. He's a samurai after all!

examples.en: Do you know the meaning of this gesture?
examples.ja: このジェスチャーの意味、分かる？

examples.en: I don't understand what you are saying.
examples.ja: あんたの言ってる意味分かんない。

examples.en: "I thought you were smarter." "Hey, what does that mean?"
examples.ja: 「あなたって、もっと頭が良いと思ってたわ。」「おい、それってどういう意味だよ！」

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>flavor</kanji> of an <kanji>idea</kanji>, what is that? Imagine yourself licking an idea to figure out what it tastes like. What do you think you'll be tasting? Probably the <vocabulary>meaning</vocabulary> of said idea.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I hope this taste will suit your palate.
examples.ja: この味、お口に合うといいんですが。

examples.en: The taste of ramen here has been the same for a long time.
examples.ja: ここのラーメンの味、昔からずーっと一緒なんだよ。

examples.en: The secret taste of this soup is puffer fish bones.
examples.ja: このスープの隠し味はフグの骨なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You may have the ability to <vocabulary>taste</vocabulary> things now, but just wait until you get up there in <reading>age</reading> (あじ). You'll find that the tastes and flavors you once liked will become bland, and you'll need a lot of Sriracha to make things taste better.

examples.en: The grocery store over there is having a sale for tomatoes this week.
examples.ja: あそこのスーパー、今週はトマトの安売りセールをやってるよ。

examples.en: Thanks to the sale, I could buy this dress for 300 yen.
examples.ja: 安売りのおかげで、このワンピースは三百円で買えたよ。

examples.en: Aren't you selling yourself short?
examples.ja: 自分を安売りしてない？

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>sell</kanji> something <kanji>cheap</kanji>, you're selling it at a <vocabulary>discount</vocabulary>. Alternatively you can remember this word as <vocabulary>sell cheaply</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bargain sale</vocabulary>. These are good deals!
reading_mnemonic: The hiragana on the end hints that the readings are the kun'yomi readings. Use your memory of 安い and 売る to help you to remember how to read this.

examples.en: I find it quite annoying, so I wanna get even.
examples.ja: ムカつくから、なんか仕返ししたいな。

examples.en: Seriously, she is the worst! I'll get even with her someday!
examples.ja: 本当に最低の女！いつか仕返ししてやるわ！

examples.en: To get back at him for eating my pudding, I ate Koichi's favorite yogurt.
examples.ja: プリンを食べられた仕返しに、コウイチの好きなヨーグルトを食べてやった。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>return</kanji> the <kanji>doing</kanji>s of another person, you're doing it to <vocabulary>get even</vocabulary> (whether it's a nice thing or a mean thing).
reading_mnemonic: The readings are a bit weird, here. 仕 gets its on'yomi reading... you should be okay with that. 返し gets the kun'yomi reading, though, which is the reading you saw with the word 返す in level 9. You can tell this part uses the kun'yomi vocab reading because it has that hiragana attached to it. Just remember to distinguish between the two parts of the word to remember the readings.

examples.en: I'll be at the office until an email comes back.
examples.ja: メールが返ってくるまで会社にいます。

examples.en: The ball that I threw came back to me with the wind.
examples.ja: 投げたボールが風で返ってきた。

examples.en: Thinking my money would be returned properly was a huge mistake.
examples.ja: 貸したお金がちゃんと返ってくると思ったら大間違いよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You hopefully know the word 返す, which means "to return" (as in, you're doing the direct action of returning something). This word, on the other hand, is the version where something just returns (and you're not doing the action of returning it). Use the る to help you to remember this. る the Kangaroo is returned to you. You don't do any of the returning, it just happens or someone else does it. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be returned</vocabulary>.

Note this word is often combined with くる (to come), which reinforces the aspect that something is coming back to you.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 返す, so as long as you know that you'll be able to apply it here to learn the reading of this word as well.

examples.en: Where is the gondola terminal?
examples.ja: ゴンドラ乗り場はどこですか？

examples.en: I'm at the taxi stand now.
examples.ja: 今、タクシー乗り場にいます。

examples.en: At the moment, I’m chilling at the bus stop in front of my house looking at cars passing by.
examples.ja: 今、家の前のバス乗り場で通り過ぎる車を見ながらダラダラしているよ。

meaning_mnemonic: What's a <kanji>ride</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji>? It's a <vocabulary>boarding area</vocabulary>! This word is used widely to refer to any place where you board transportation, such as a <vocabulary>bus stop</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>taxi stand</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>train platform</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

At the <vocabulary>boarding area</vocabulary>, you <reading>baa</reading> (ば) at the bus driver to ask if this is the right bus. You're in a country inhabited only by sheep, but luckily you've practiced your Sheepanese well enough to be able to baa for directions at <vocabulary>bus stop</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>taxi stand</vocabulary>s, and <vocabulary>train platform</vocabulary>s.

examples.en: You should be more careful about how you use language.
examples.ja: もう少し、言葉の使い方に気を付けた方がいいよ。

examples.en: Grandpa always calls because he doesn't know how to use his smartphone or computer.
examples.ja: おじいちゃんはスマホやパソコンの使い方が分からないので、いつも電話をしてきます。

examples.en: How to use Excel? Even my dog knows that.
examples.ja: エクセルの使い方？そんなのうちの犬でも知ってるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word 使う hopefully by now. If you have, you know it means "to use." So, the <kanji>way</kanji> to <kanji>use</kanji> something is the <vocabulary>way of using</vocabulary> (aka <vocabulary>how to use</vocabulary>). This will be a word you see when you're looking at directions for how to use something.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 使う and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.
