examples.en: Since I started a new job, it has only been three days.
examples.ja: 新しい仕事を始めてから、まだ三日です。

examples.en: I won't be able to sign off work until six o'clock today, so stay in a nearby cafe until then.
examples.ja: 今日は六時まで仕事が終わらないから、それまで近くのカフェにいてね。

examples.en: The baby's job is to cry.
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんの仕事は泣くことです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "thing." So when you're <kanji>doing</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s all day, what are you probably doing? A <vocabulary>job</vocabulary>! All jobs really just amount to doing things.

Just like "job" in English, 仕事 can refer to a person's specific <vocabulary>occupation</vocabulary>, to <vocabulary>work</vocabulary> in general, or to a particular task depending on the context.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 仕 and the kun'yomi reading for 事. Please note that 事 uses the reading こと, which you didn't learn with the kanji, but you have come across it once or twice by now, and because of the way rendaku works, it's changed to the voiced ごと.

examples.en: I don't think you're a loser.
examples.ja: 私はあなたのことを負け犬だとは思わないよ。

examples.en: If I am living like this, I'll just continue to be a loser in life.
examples.ja: こんな生活をしてたら、ずっと人生の負け犬だよ。

examples.en: I don't want to be called a loser anymore.
examples.ja: 負け犬と呼ばれるのは、もう嫌なんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully come across 負ける by now, which means "to lose." So, you can figure out this word means "losing dog." Well, calling someone a dog isn't so nice, so you're probably just calling them a <vocabulary>loser</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi, but you should be familiar with 負ける and of course 犬 well enough to learn the reading here.

examples.en: Japan's team won today's game.
examples.ja: 今日のゲームは日本チームの勝ちでした。

examples.en: The key chain is first come, first served. Let’s get a move on!
examples.ja: キーホールダーがもらえるの早い者勝ちなんだって。早く行こう！

examples.en: If that ace is on the mound, we don't stand a chance of winning.
examples.ja: あのエースがマウンドに立っていたら、私たちには勝ち目がないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 勝つ by now, which means "to win." This is a nouny version of that. So, what's the noun version of "to win?" It's <vocabulary>a win</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>victory</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 勝つ. So as long as you have some understanding of that reading, you should be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: There are many people who suffer from long hours at work in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本には長時間労働に苦しむ人が多くいます。

examples.en: I don't want to go to school while suffering from bullying.
examples.ja: いじめに苦しみながら学校に行きたくないよ。

examples.en: Why do innocent people suffer?
examples.ja: なぜ罪のない人が苦しんでいるのか。

meaning_mnemonic: You've already been introduced to the word 苦しい. That word means painful, or agonizing. So, if you turn that into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to suffer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to struggle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 苦しい, so as long as you're on top of that word, this word should be readable for you as well.

examples.en: It took me some time to realize that the woman was my own mother.
examples.ja: その女が自分の母だと気付くまでに時間がかかりました。

examples.en: When I noticed, it was already time to go to school.
examples.ja: 気づいたらもう学校に行く時間だった。

examples.en: I can’t believe you gave me your ice cream. I didn’t realize that you were so kind until now.
examples.ja: あんたが私にアイスクリームをくれるなんて、本当に信じられないよ。あんたがそんなに優しいなんて今まで気付かなかったわ！

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>attach</kanji> your <kanji>energy</kanji> (imagine someone suddenly looking up at something, attaching their energy to it), you have noticed or realized something. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to realize</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to notice</vocabulary>. 

Don't confuse this with 気を付けて which is similar in that it has all the same kanji. It's just used a little different. Try to remember the difference before moving on.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the 気 kanji (which you know) and the word 付く which you should know by now. Combine these together and you have the ability to read this word. Take note that the 付く part is rendaku'd, though, so it is a tiny bit different.

examples.en: Which do you like being better? One who sees someone off, or one who is seen off by someone.
examples.ja: 見送る方と見送られる方、どっちが良い？

examples.en: I went to Tokyo to see them off.
examples.ja: 東京まで見送りに行った。

examples.en: He passed up a chance to go abroad.
examples.ja: 彼は海外に行くチャンスを見送った。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the words 見る and 送る by now, hopefully. Here you're "seeing" the "sending." You're seeing someone off, so this verb is <vocabulary>to see off</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>to put off</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pass on</vocabulary>, since it's as though you're just passively seeing someone (or something) off rather than taking action and going with them.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the vocab words 見る and 送る. Make sure you know those and you'll know this word's reading as well.

examples.en: I go to the convenience store from time to time.
examples.ja: そこのコンビニは時々行きます。

examples.en: Sometimes I wonder what Koichi is doing at the moment.
examples.ja: 時々「コウイチは今何してるかな？」って思うんだよね。

examples.en: Sometimes there were problems with my neighbors.
examples.ja: ご近所とのトラブルは時々ありました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the single word 時, right? It means <kanji>time</kanji>. This is that twice. So you have one time, and you have another time. They are separate. Things don't happen in every of these times you have. They happen <vocabulary>sometimes</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab word 時 twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd.

examples.en: Please first go to the receptionist.
examples.ja: まずは受付に行ってください。

examples.en: Even the reception staff at that gym are ripped.
examples.ja: あそこのジムは受付スタッフまでマッチョだね。

examples.en: Have you already checked in at reception?
examples.ja: 受付の手続きはもうお済みですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Imagine someone <kanji>accept</kanji>ing something and then <kanji>attach</kanji>ing something. This person is a <vocabulary>receptionist</vocabulary>, because they are accepting the call, writing down the information, and then attaching said information to a sticky note for you to read. You say, "No, I'm not available."
reading_mnemonic: For this reading you have to think back to the verb words that get used with this kanji, namely 受ける and 付ける. Then just drop off the るs and put them together. 受 becomes うけ and 付 becomes つけ and you're left with うけつけ. This is what's called a compound word. And now you know it. Nice!

examples.en: I've just done the grocery shopping.
examples.ja: スーパーで買い物をしたばかりです。

examples.en: Let's go shopping at a department store sometime.
examples.ja: たまにはデパートに買い物に行こうよ。

examples.en: We’re going Christmas shopping today! I’m so excited!
examples.ja: 今日はクリスマスの買い物に行くの！すごくワクワクするわ！

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 買う by now and know it means "to buy." So, 買い is going to be similar to that. Add that to <kanji>thing</kanji> and you have a "buying things" sort of word. What does "buying things" describe? It describes <vocabulary>shopping</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi, which is usually the case when there's hiragana in the middle. You learned the reading for 買い when you learned the kanji, as well as the word 買う, and you learned this reading of 物 in the word 物!

examples.en: I'm not a big fan of celery.
examples.ja: セロリが苦手です。

examples.en: The drawback about that idol is that she is not a good singer.
examples.ja: あのアイドル、歌が苦手なのが欠点なんだよな。

examples.en: Why does my dog bark only at you? He probably just doesn't like you.
examples.ja: うちの犬がなんでお前にばっかり吠えるかって？たぶん、お前のことが苦手なんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A "suffering hand" is a little misleading. Think more in terms of the words 苦い (bitter) and 手 (person... remember how that happens sometimes?). Now think of this word like you're bitter about having to work with someone. Why? Because they are extremely <vocabulary>hard to deal with</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is that of 苦い (にがい) plus regular old 手 (て). Remember, this is your bitter person, the person who's "hard to deal with." So, it uses the strange にがい reading.

examples.en: Viet's hair style today kind of looks like a delinquent's, don't you think?
examples.ja: ビエト、今日はちょっと不良っぽいヘアスタイルだね。

examples.en: The malfunctioning parts were found.
examples.ja: 不良パーツが見つかりました。

examples.en: That delinquent girl suddenly stopped coming to school, and the next thing we knew, she had apparently joined a gang.
examples.ja: あの不良少女は、いきなり学校に来なくなったと思えば、ギャングに入ったそうなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good</kanji> is <vocabulary>bad</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>substandard</vocabulary>. This usage is more formal and frequently paired with other kanji compounds. Alternatively, it can refer to someone who is a  <vocabulary>delinquent</vocabulary>, in which case it is often used as a standalone word.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This blanket feels really good.
examples.ja: このブランケット、気持ちいい。

examples.en: Doesn't it feel good to have a clean house?
examples.ja: 家がきれいだと気持ちいいよね！

examples.en: It looks like I felt so comfortable that I was snoring during the massage.
examples.ja: マッサージ中、気持ち良すぎてイビキをかいてたみたい。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have a "feeling" (気持ち) that is いい (that means "good" by the way), you have a <vocabulary>good feeling</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab word 気持ち, so if you know that (or the vocab words 気 and 持ち) you should be A-okay on this one. Maybe even <vocabulary>feeling good</vocabulary> about it?

examples.en: Try this supplement.
examples.ja: このサプリ、試して。

examples.en: I tried various diets, but none of them worked.
examples.ja: 色々なダイエットを試したけど、どれもダメだったよ。

examples.en: I don’t know if I can lick my elbow, but I’ll give it a try.
examples.ja: 肘を舐めれるかどうかは分からないけど、試しにやってみるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>attempt</kanji> or <kanji>try</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to try something out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to give something a try</vocabulary>. Why don't you try out the meaning of this verb, while you're at it?
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Okay. Here's the deal. We have this wild animal. I want you <vocabulary>to attempt</vocabulary> to <reading>tame</reading> (ため) it. Now, imagine trying to tame this wild animal. Yeehaw!

examples.en: If you compare these two pictures, you can clearly see that she had plastic surgery.
examples.ja: この二つの写真を比べると、整形したのがハッキリ分かるよ。

examples.en: Why don't you compare it with other textbooks before you decide?
examples.ja: 他のテキストと比べてみてから決めたら？

examples.en: The number of WaniKani users is lower compared to last year. What should we do?
examples.ja: 去年と比べてワニカニユーザーの数が減っているんです。どうしましょう？

examples.en: Compared to that, my case is still not that bad.
examples.ja: それに比べれば、ボクのケースなんてまだマシだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>compare</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to compare</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Look at this <reading>cooler</reading> (くら). Now look at this other cooler. We need <vocabulary>to  compare</vocabulary> the two coolers. Think about all the features each one has and really compare, like you have a list or something.

examples.en: Two months are left until the entrance exam.
examples.ja: 入学試験まで、あと二ヶ月です。

examples.en: The entrance examination costs a lot.
examples.ja: 入学試験には、たくさんお金がかかった。

examples.en: What! She's failed the entrance exam?
examples.ja: ええっ！入学試験に落ちちゃったの？

meaning_mnemonic: For <kanji>school admission</kanji> (入学) you're taking an <kanji>examination</kanji> (試験). What exams do you have to take to get into a school? How about <vocabulary>entrance exam</vocabulary>s? The Japanese ones are pretty hard. Another word for them is "hell tests."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It'll also help if you know the two separate words that make up this longer word.

examples.en: Oh, you have a brother and a sister. That's unexpected.
examples.ja: あなた弟と妹がいるの？意外だね。

examples.en: Unexpectedly, my weight has dropped.
examples.ja: 意外と体重は落ちてた。

examples.en: Liking soft pasta that's been cooked too long was an unexpected aspect of Canadian culture.
examples.ja: ゆですぎの柔らかいパスタを好んで食べるのは、カナダの意外な文化でした。

meaning_mnemonic: Something <kanji>outside</kanji> your normal <kanji>idea</kanji> of how things work will come as <vocabulary>unexpected</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>surprising</vocabulary> to you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That's correct!
examples.ja: 正解です！

examples.en: We were right about keeping it a secret from Koichi.
examples.ja: コウイチにはヒミツにしておいて、正解だったね。

examples.en: Among you, the only one who got the correct answer was Jenny.
examples.ja: 正解を出したのは、君たちの中ではジェニーだけでした。

meaning_mnemonic: It is <kanji>correct</kanji> you have <kanji>solve</kanji>d the answer, getting the <vocabulary>correct answer</vocabulary>. You'll see this on Japanese game shows a lot. 正解！！！
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Who is that person?
examples.ja: あの人、誰かな？

examples.en: Whose turn is it next?
examples.ja: 次は誰の番？

examples.en: Oh, who said that?
examples.ja: え、それ、誰が言ったの？

examples.en: "I wonder who that girl is." "You don’t know her name? She sits behind you in class!"
examples.ja: 「彼女は誰かしら。」「名前を知らないの？クラスであなたの後ろに座っているよ！」

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: These spoons come with a case.
examples.ja: このスプーンはケース付きですよ。

examples.en: Is there a hotel with a pool around here?
examples.ja: この辺にプール付きのホテルはありますか？

examples.en: This room is furnished with a refrigerator and a washing machine.
examples.ja: この部屋は冷蔵庫、洗濯機付きです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji 付 means <kanji>attach</kanji> and words like 付く mean "to be attached." This has the same idea. When you see this attached to another word, for example, you might know that something is attached to something else, or perhaps <vocabulary>included</vocabulary> with it. For example, if you stay at a hotel room, maybe it is a breakfast付き, i.e. "<vocabulary>including</vocabulary> breakfast."
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji as well as from words like 付く and 付ける.

examples.en: I thought that at least Tofugu would support me.
examples.ja: トーフグだけは、味方してくれると思ってたんだけどな。

examples.en: Dad pretends to be my big sister's ally, but he's actually always on my side.
examples.ja: お父さんは、お姉ちゃんの味方のフリをするが、いつでも私の味方だ。

examples.en: Just which side are you on?!
examples.ja: お前は一体どっちの味方なんだ？

meaning_mnemonic: You like the <kanji>flavor</kanji> of a particular <kanji>direction</kanji>, so you go that way. Everyone else going in the same flavor direction is your <vocabulary>ally</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>supporter</vocabulary>. They're your flavor direction allies. They have the same tastes and they're chasing the same flavors in life, so naturally they become allies, right?
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the on'yomi reading for 味, but the kun'yomi reading for 方, so watch out for that! You're probably more familiar with the on'yomi for 方, so here's a mnemonic to help with the kun'yomi:

A good <vocabulary>ally</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>supporter</vocabulary> is always ready to <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた) you into the best positions. They believe in you so they want what's best for you.

examples.en: Is the Year-End Jumbo Draw Lottery still for sale?
examples.ja: 年末ジャンボ宝くじはまだ発売中ですか？

examples.en: This ice-cream is on sale at convenience stores nationwide.
examples.ja: このアイスは全国のコンビニで発売中です。

examples.en: The June issue of Shonen Jump is now on sale, to critical acclaim.
examples.ja: 少年ジャンプ６月号、ただ今絶賛発売中。

meaning_mnemonic: You have 発売, which means "for sale," and then you have 中 which is <kanji>middle</kanji>. An item that is in the middle of being for sale is <vocabulary>now for sale</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>in stores now</vocabulary> or in other words <vocabulary>now available</vocabulary>. You'll see this for items which have recently been released or when a shopkeeper wants to let you know that they're selling something now, finally, or whatever.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 発売 and 中 (kanji reading) put together.

examples.en: Please bring some food, Ms. Yasuda.
examples.ja: 安田さんは、食べ物をおねがいします。

examples.en: Is this really food? It looks like a stone.
examples.ja: これは本当に食べ物ですか？石みたいですが。

examples.en: When you waste food, heaven will punish you.
examples.ja: 食べ物を粗末にするとバチが当たりますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>eat</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> (aka "a thing you eat") is <vocabulary>food</vocabulary>. Eat those things. Eat that food. Because it's a "thing" you know it's a noun. Interesting how this kanji can turn a verb like this into a noun, right? Look out for it because this pattern will show up with other verbs as well!
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: Today's waves are very high, aren't they?
examples.ja: 今日の波、すごく高いね。

examples.en: Those are the best waves for surfers.
examples.ja: サーファーにとっては最高の波だよ。

examples.en: The ocean today is quiet and has no waves at all.
examples.ja: 今日の海、波が全然なくて静かだね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:

You jump on a wave and ride around the world on it. As you ride this wave, it gets bigger and bigger, until it reaches tsu<reading>nami</reading> (なみ) proportions. Imagine looking down from the tsunami at the vast, blue sea all around you. That's quite a wave you're riding.

examples.en: It's not too big or too small. It's just the right size.
examples.ja: 大きすぎず、小さすぎず、本当に丁度いいサイズです。

examples.en: Oh, you came at the right time!
examples.ja: あっ、丁度いいところに来たね！

examples.en: This temperature is just right.
examples.ja: このぐらいの温度が丁度いいですね。

meaning_mnemonic: If 丁度 is "exactly", then "exactly good" is going to be just the right amount, aka <vocabulary>just right</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know the reading for 丁度 you'll know the reading for this too. Your knowledge should be <vocabulary>just right</vocabulary>, as they say inside my head.

examples.en: I am worried about keeping a high fluency in Japanese if I go to America.
examples.ja: アメリカに行ったら高い日本語力を保持できるか不安です。

examples.en: It is quite impressive to maintain this quality.
examples.ja: このクオリティを保持するのは中々すごいことなんですよ。

examples.en: You should prioritize maintaining your own country’s status first.
examples.ja: 自国の地位を保持することをまず優先した方がいい。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is the verb version of 保持 (keep), so this means <vocabulary>to keep</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to hold</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to maintain</vocabulary>.

Note that this is a formal word that's commonly used in professional or official contexts.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 保持, so if you know that word's reading, you know this one too.

examples.en: What, are you commuting from Tokyo to Kyushu every day?
examples.ja: えっ、東京から九州まで毎日通ってるの？

examples.en: Koichi goes to the company by Harley.
examples.ja: コウイチは、会社までハーレーで通っています。

examples.en: My younger sister will attend Tofugu Academy starting in April.
examples.ja: 私の妹は、四月からトーフグ学園に通うことになります。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>pass through</kanji> but we already know the word 通る which means to pass through. This word means a different kind of passing through, like how you pass through the halls of your school everyday. But we don't say to pass through school, we say <vocabulary>to attend</vocabulary> school, or <vocabulary>to commute</vocabulary> to school.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You live in the middle of three different school districts so you need to decide which of the three schools you want <vocabulary>to attend</vocabulary>. You decide you don't mind that you have <vocabulary>to commute</vocabulary> to the farthest of the three because their mascot is Wile E. <reading>Coyo</reading>te (かよ). He's your favorite Looney Toon because he always has the energy <vocabulary>to go back and forth</vocabulary> after that road runner.

examples.en: I belonged to a volleyball club back in junior high school.
examples.ja: 中学の時は、バレーボール部でした。

examples.en: I just joined the digital solution department at the company.
examples.ja: あそこの会社のデジタルソリューション部に入ったばかりなんです。

examples.en: I’m the head of the accounting department.
examples.ja: 経理部の部長をしています。

meaning_mnemonic: You'll see this attached to other words... like "sales" or "tennis." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ department, or a ___ club, making this word mean <vocabulary>department</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>club</vocabulary>, similar to the kanji meaning.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

examples.en: We're doing a rooftop barbecue today.
examples.ja: 今日、屋上でバーベキューをします。

examples.en: We grow tomatoes on the rooftop of this building.
examples.ja: このビルの屋上ではトマトを育てています。

examples.en: On the rooftop, we dry our laundry during the day and see the stars at night.
examples.ja: 屋上では、昼は洗濯物を干したり、夜は星を見たりするんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Above</kanji> the <kanji>roof</kanji> is the <vocabulary>rooftop</vocabulary>. What else would be up there?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 屋 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

One place in the world has more <vocabulary>rooftop</vocabulary>s than any where else, and that's <reading>Ok</reading>lahoma (おく). They get so many tornadoes that they need extra rooftops for when the first few blow off.

examples.en: I got candles and a lighter ready in case of an emergency.
examples.ja: もしもの時のためにキャンドルとライターを用意しました。

examples.en: Are you done getting things ready for school tomorrow?
examples.ja: 明日の学校の用意はもう出来た？

examples.en: We will do all the nabe party arrangements to celebrate the release from jail, so please take care of making arrangements for bail on your side.
examples.ja: 出所祝いの鍋パーティーの用意は全てこちらで致しますので、あなたは保釈金の用意をお願いします。

meaning_mnemonic:
This <kanji>task</kanji> is just an <kanji>idea</kanji> because you're still doing <vocabulary>preparation</vocabulary> for it. You're <vocabulary>getting ready</vocabulary>. Once you finish that, the task idea can become a task reality, but until then you're just preparing.

用意 means having something ready for a specific purpose. Meals, cars, rooms, and even umbrellas are all things you might get to a state of readiness with your 用意. And once it's 用意'd, that means it's set and ready to go.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I can't do without yoga in my daily life.
examples.ja: 毎日の生活にヨガは欠かせません。

examples.en: Every single member of this team is essential and valuable.
examples.ja: このチームのメンバーは一人も欠かせない、大切なメンバーです。

examples.en: I cannot live without my cell phone.
examples.ja: 私の生活に、携帯電話を欠かすことはできない。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 欠 means <kanji>lack</kanji>? This verb is related. The 欠かす form is a little tricky, but it's sort of like you're causing yourself to lack something. So it means <vocabulary>to do without</vocabulary>. Depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>to miss an event</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fail to do</vocabulary> something. Just keep in mind this word is most often used in the negative, like 欠かせないもの (things you can't do without) or 朝のコーヒーは欠かさない (never go without morning coffee).

You can remember 欠かす this way: Since you cause yourself to lack something with this word, it's all your fault. That's why you want to <reading>cuss</reading> (かす). You made yourself miss out on something. Well, $*%!!!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: I'm looking forward to seeing the old town.
examples.ja: 昔の町を見物するのが楽しみです。

examples.en: The town is full of people who came to see the Christmas parade.
examples.ja: クリスマスパレードを見物しにきた人々で町がいっぱいです。

examples.en: Mom would have gone sightseeing in Tokyo.
examples.ja: 母ちゃんなら、東京見物に出かけたぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <kanji>see</kanji> a bunch of <kanji>thing</kanji>s at once, you are probably <vocabulary>sightseeing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>watching</vocabulary>. This can also refer to the person doing the action, so it can sometimes mean <vocabulary>sightseer</vocabulary> too.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, and you know how to read 物. 見's on'yomi (けん) is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji because it's so much less useful, but you do have to know it here. You've seen it with 発見 a couple levels ago, so that should help. Just imagine taking the samurai <reading>Ken</reading> on an epic <vocabulary>sightseeing</vocabulary> trip. Think of all the things you and Ken will visit!

examples.en: I knew it would happen, so I prepared ahead of time.
examples.ja: こうなることは分かっていたので、予め用意しておきました。

examples.en: I checked in online on the day before the flight.
examples.ja: 予めフライト前日にオンラインでチェックインしておきました。

examples.en: Preparing the lesson in advance was worthwhile.
examples.ja: 予め予習しておいた甲斐がありました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that 予め is mostly used in formal contexts like meetings, announcements or notices, and business emails.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

At the Last Supper, the apostles asked <vocabulary>beforehand</vocabulary>: "Can we order <reading>à la car</reading>te, <reading>Je</reading>sus (あらかじ)?" Jesus said no, but He also knew <vocabulary>ahead of time</vocabulary> that Judas would betray Him by ordering some expensive à la carte dishes. And also by doing that other thing.

examples.en: Can you read hiragana?
examples.ja: 平仮名は読めますか？

examples.en: I want to name my child with hiragana.
examples.ja: うちの子には平仮名の名前をつけたいんです。

examples.en: If you eat this chocolate, you can memorize all of the hiragana.
examples.ja: このチョコレートを食べると平仮名を全部おぼえることができますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 仮名 means "kana?" Well this is <kanji>flat</kanji> kana. Flat kana is just <vocabulary>hiragana</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You should know the reading for this word because it's the same as the English meaning.

examples.en: This child is literally a genius.
examples.ja: この子は文字通り「天才」だ。

examples.en: With the kanji 目 and 玉, 目玉 literally means "eye ball."
examples.ja: 目と玉という漢字の文字通り、目玉は「eye ball」という意味です。

examples.en: "Tsundere" literally means, "acting cold in public but acting lovestruck in private".
examples.ja: ツンデレとは、文字通り「人前ではツンツンしているけど二人の時はデレデレすること」です。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned the words 文字 and 通り? Well an "avenue" made of "letters" is <vocabulary>literally</vocabulary> <vocabulary>to the letter</vocabulary>. Wink.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 文字 and 通り, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this one. Just make sure you remember that とおり becomes どおり because of rendaku.

examples.en: Start squatting on my signal.
examples.ja: 相図をしたら、スクワットを始めて下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>diagram</kanji> is one that's for everyone to see. It's a <vocabulary>sign</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: We made a video to teach you the ABCs of how to use WaniKani.
examples.ja: ワニカニの使い方の初歩を教えるビデオを作りました。

examples.en: My father taught me the basics of this game.
examples.ja: 父は、このゲームの初歩をおしえてくれました。

examples.en: I’m starting to study the basics of French.
examples.ja: フランス語を初歩から学び始めました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> thing you <kanji>walk</kanji> through when you learn something new will always be the <vocabulary>basics</vocabulary>. You never start by running, you always have to start slow and work your way through the <vocabulary>ABCs</vocabulary> before you start to run.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You will be able to go to a new stage when you level up.
examples.ja: レベルアップすると、新たなステージに行くことができますよ。

examples.en: I have a feeling that September will be a new beginning for me.
examples.ja: 九月は自分にとって新たなスタートになりそうな気がする。

examples.en: Every time I reread this novel I make a new discovery.
examples.ja: この小説は、読み返す度に新たな発見がある。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>new</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>new</vocabulary> too.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Your parents put a <vocabulary>newly</vocabulary> wrapped present under the Christmas tree. You don't want to wait to see what new thing they got you so you rip it open to find they got you <reading>a ra</reading>w (あら) steak. Getting a new steak is cool and all, but a raw steak is pretty gross. It's dripping blood all over the place.

examples.en: I haven't been to any western countries yet.
examples.ja: 西洋の国にはまだ行ったことがないんです。

examples.en: We could say hugging is a part of Western culture.
examples.ja: ハグは西洋の文化だと言えるでしょう。

examples.en: Do Westerners spend their time in shoes at their homes?
examples.ja: 西洋人は家の中で靴を履いて過ごすんですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Go <kanji>west</kanji> until you encounter <kanji>Western style</kanji> buildings and customs and languages everywhere. Hey, you've made it to <vocabulary>the West</vocabulary>! 

西洋 refers to <vocabulary>Western countries</vocabulary>, especially European and English-speaking countries. It's the same kind of "West" that people mean when they talk about <vocabulary>Western</vocabulary> culture and all that.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading yet for 西 (せい), so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

People are attacking from <vocabulary>the West</vocabulary>, so you pull out your <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) and beat them back. You keep pushing further and further west until you reach the ocean and there's nowhere left for them to run. Your saber saves the day! Take that, the West.

examples.en: The length of each side of this square is four centimeters.
examples.ja: この正方形の辺の長さは、それぞれ四センチです。

examples.en: Please measure the lengths of the sides of this triangle with a ruler.
examples.ja: この三角形の辺の長さをモノサシではかってみてください。

examples.en: This is an isosceles triangle.
examples.ja: これは二等辺三角形です。

meaning_mnemonic: One of the kanji meanings is <kanji>side</kanji>, and as a standalone word this also means <vocabulary>side</vocabulary>, as in the sides of a shape.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I saw Koichi walking with a different girl.
examples.ja: コウイチが、別の女と歩いているところを見たの。

examples.en: This and that are two different stories.
examples.ja: それとこれとは話が別だろう。

examples.en: Aside from that case, it's usually okay to separate the sexes in this way.
examples.ja: その場合は別として、このやり方で男女を別にするのは通常問題ありません。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Keeping positive feelings is important for anything.
examples.ja: 何事もポジティブな心持ちが大切だよね。

examples.en: Isn't this curry kind of too much for one person?
examples.ja: このカレー、一人分にしては心持ち多くない？

examples.en: He is a pleasant, honest kid.
examples.ja: あの子は、心持ちのよい素直な子です。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>hold</kanji>s a lot of <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>s. They can be overwhelming and sometimes it feels like there are none in there at all, but that doesn't mean they aren't there in your heart.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the words 心 and 持つ, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Is this a Japanese folk tale?
examples.ja: これは日本の昔話ですか。

examples.en: You're like a princess that appears in an old tale.
examples.ja: まるで昔話の中に出てくるプリンセスみたいね。

examples.en: While waiting for a bus in the bus shelter, I read a folk tale picture book for my child.
examples.ja: バス待合所でバスを待ちながら、昔話の絵本を子どもに読み聞かせた。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Long ago</kanji> people used to <kanji>talk</kanji> about all sorts of things. Most of them weren't true. Long ago people liked to lie a lot. Now we call those things they talked about <vocabulary>folk tale</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the rendaku of はなし to ばなし.

examples.en: That's a splendid tree.
examples.ja: 見事な木ですね。

examples.en: Splendid! Wow, that was such a beautiful shot!
examples.ja: お見事！いやー、実に見事なシュートだった！

examples.en: I was rejected so magnificently that it almost felt good.
examples.ja: 気持ちいいぐらい見事にフラれたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Learner, if you <kanji>see</kanji> a <kanji>thing</kanji>, then it must be <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary>. You saw it, after all, so of course it's <vocabulary>magnificent</vocabulary>. You only see the <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary> things in this world. And that's an <vocabulary>admirable</vocabulary> quality.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that there is rendaku on こと and it becomes ごと.

examples.en: I enjoy biology classes the most at school.
examples.ja: 学校で生物学のクラスが一番楽しいです。

examples.en: Mr. Kawada is a biology scholar.
examples.ja: 川田さんは生物学の学者さんです。

examples.en: If you want to become a designer, you should also study biology.
examples.ja: デザイナーになりたいなら、生物学も学んだ方がいい。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 生物 means "living things?" Well when you <kanji>study</kanji> living things you're studying <vocabulary>biology</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Have you read the pitcher's life story?
examples.ja: あの投手の伝記、読んだ？

examples.en: The stuff that was written in the writer's biography was very surprising.
examples.ja: その作家の伝記に書かれていたことは、とても意外だった。

examples.en: Well, I think I might feel like this because I was influenced by a biography I read recently.
examples.ja: まあ、そう思うのは、最近読んだ伝記の影響かもしれません。

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>transmit</kanji> the story of someone's life, you have to <kanji>write down</kanji> all of it in a <vocabulary>biography</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I rolled a stone.
examples.ja: 石を転がした。

examples.en: Just when I just rolled the dice, the phone rung.
examples.ja: ちょうどサイコロを転がした時、電話が来た。

examples.en: Dung beetles are called “poop rollers” because they roll poop.
examples.ja: Dung beetleは、フンを転がすことから「フンコロガシ」と言います。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>revolve</kanji>, and the verb version is when you make something revolve. You roll it. That's why this verb is <vocabulary>to roll something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means you roll something else, like a ball. Or, if you're a dung beetle, poop. 💩 Not to be confused with 転がる, which is intransitive, like so many verbs ending in がる.
reading_mnemonic:
You learned this reading when you learned 転がる, but here's a mnemonic anyway just in case:

When you try <vocabulary>to roll something</vocabulary>, the outside bits may be moving, but its <reading>core</reading> (ころ) stays still. Picture yourself making the earth roll across the floor. The outside parts where the people live are spinning round and round, but the earth's core is in exactly the same place.

examples.en: Please continue your interview.
examples.ja: どうぞ、インタビューを進めて下さい。

examples.en: With this snow, we can't move the construction forward anymore.
examples.ja: この雪じゃ、これ以上工事を進められないよ。

examples.en: Please move your work forward at the current pace.
examples.ja: このペースで作業を進めてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>advance</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to advance something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to move something forward</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, so you act upon something else. You advance something. You move something forward. Like a school project, or your plans for taking over the world.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help:

You are moving your lawsuit forward against Sue. But now she says that YOU'RE the problem. "<reading>Sue, sue me</reading>," (すすめ) you say as you continue to advance the lawsuit. Make sure to say "me" like "mehh," in a really snobbish way.

examples.en: I think your banana-only diet lacks balance.
examples.ja: バナナだけの食事はバランスを欠いていると思いますよ。

examples.en: Raw fish can't help but lack freshness three days after purchase.
examples.ja: 生の魚は、買った三日後には、どうしてもフレッシュさを欠きますね。

examples.en: The internet is an indispensable service in our lives.
examples.ja: インターネットは私たちの生活に欠くことのできないサービスだ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lack, and this verb means to lack something. Pretty simple in English, but 欠く is actually kind of advanced and formal in Japanese, so it's mostly just used in writing. Also keep in mind this is a transitive verb, so 欠く takes a direct object — maybe someone lacks knowledge, for example, or you lack concentration. This is a bit different from saying "your concentration is lacking," at least grammatically. (For that, you'd use 欠ける.)
reading_mnemonic:
You learned this reading when you learned 欠ける, but here's a mnemonic just in case:

You never know when you're going <vocabulary>to lack something</vocabulary>. Like a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Did you plan for it to break? NO! But it happened and now you lack a car in a big way. Not <reading>cool</reading> (く)!

examples.en: It started raining right before we left.
examples.ja: 出発の直前に雨がふりだした。

examples.en: I fell down right before the goal.
examples.ja: ゴール直前でこけてしまった。

examples.en: Because it was a last-minute cancellation, I hardly got any money back.
examples.ja: 直前のキャンセルだったので、お金はほとんどもどってこなかった。

examples.en: Just as I was about to eat sushi, I realized there was no soy sauce.
examples.ja: すしを食べる直前にしょうゆがないと気づいたんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something happened <kanji>direct</kanji>ly <kanji>before</kanji> this. In other words, it happened <vocabulary>just before</vocabulary> this.

直前 is used to talk about something happening <vocabulary>immediately prior to</vocabulary> something else, like when your date cancels on you just before you were supposed to meet or your doctor tells you not to eat a snack right before bed.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
